supporting.text: Tiger sharks, like many other shark species, are obligate ram ventilators, meaning they must continuously swim to pass water over their gills for oxygen uptake.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks, like many other shark species, are obligate ram ventilators, meaning they must continuously swim to pass water over their gills for oxygen uptake.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting or moving very slowly near the ocean floor, suggesting they may not always need to swim continuously.
These observations of resting tiger sharks are rare and may involve unique physiological adaptations not representative of the species as a whole.
Tiger sharks in captivity have been documented using buccal pumping (actively moving water over gills without swimming) in certain conditions.
Buccal pumping in captive tiger sharks is energetically inefficient and not observed in wild populations, making it an exception rather than the norm.

supporting.text: Scientific studies confirm that tiger sharks cannot actively pump water over their gills like some bony fish, requiring constant movement to respire.

attacks.text: Scientific studies confirm that tiger sharks cannot actively pump water over their gills like some bony fish, requiring constant movement to respire.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting motionless on the ocean floor, suggesting they can respire without continuous swimming.
The observed resting behavior is rare and may rely on localized water currents or tidal movements to facilitate respiration passively.
Tiger sharks in captivity have survived in tanks with minimal water flow, indicating alternative respiration mechanisms.
Captive environments are highly controlled and may not reflect natural physiological constraints faced in the wild.

supporting.text: Observations of tiger sharks in the wild show they exhibit near-continuous swimming behavior, even during rest periods.

attacks.text: Observations of tiger sharks in the wild show they exhibit near-continuous swimming behavior, even during rest periods.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting motionless on the ocean floor, contradicting the claim of continuous swimming.
Motionless resting behavior in tiger sharks is rare and likely occurs only in specific environments with low oxygen demand.
Tiger sharks, like all sharks, must swim to breathe due to ram ventilation, making continuous swimming physiologically necessary.
Some sharks, including tiger sharks, can switch to buccal pumping (actively moving water over gills) in low-speed or stationary scenarios.

supporting.text: Unlike some shark species that can use buccal pumping to breathe while stationary, tiger sharks lack this anatomical adaptation.

attacks.text: Unlike some shark species that can use buccal pumping to breathe while stationary, tiger sharks lack this anatomical adaptation.
Tiger sharks have been observed resting motionless on the ocean floor in certain environments, suggesting they may have alternative methods for respiration.
These observations of resting tiger sharks are rare and may involve unique physiological states or environmental conditions not typical for the species.
Some studies suggest tiger sharks can engage in ram ventilation at very low speeds, reducing the need for constant swimming.
Ram ventilation at low speeds still requires some movement and does not equate to complete stationary breathing like buccal pumping species.

supporting.text: Marine biology textbooks classify tiger sharks as obligate ram ventilators, supporting the claim that they cannot stop swimming.

attacks.text: Marine biology textbooks classify tiger sharks as obligate ram ventilators, supporting the claim that they cannot stop swimming.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting or moving very slowly near the ocean floor, suggesting they may not always need to swim continuously.
These observations of resting tiger sharks are rare and may involve sick or injured individuals, not representative of healthy populations.
Obligate ram ventilation does not necessarily mean sharks cannot stop swimming, only that they require forward motion to breathe efficiently.
Marine biologists define obligate ram ventilators as species that cannot actively pump water over their gills and thus must keep moving to breathe.
